review.title: Mining the Web for Pharmacovigilance: the Case Study of Duloxetine and Venlafaxine
review.abstract: Adverse reactions caused by drugs following their release into the market are among the leading causes of death in many countries. The rapid growth of electronically available health related information, and the ability to process large volumes of them automatically, using natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning algorithms, have opened new opportunities for pharmacovigilance. Survey found that more than 70% of US Internet users consult the Internet when they require medical information. In recent years, research in this area has addressed for Adverse Drug Reaction (ADR) pharmacovigilance using social media, mainly Twitter and medical forums and websites. This paper will show the information which can be collected from a variety of Internet data sources and search engines, mainly Google Trends and Google Correlate. While considering the case study of two popular Major depressive Disorder (MDD) drugs, Duloxetine and Venlafaxine, we will provide a comparative analysis for their reactions using publicly-available alternative data sources.

metadata.title: Mining the Web for Pharmacovigilance: the Case Study of Duloxetine and Venlafaxine

sections.text: The rapid growth of electronically available health information and the ability to process large amounts automatically using natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning algorithms have opened up new opportunities for pharmacovigilance. Surveys show that more than 70% of US Internet users consult the Internet when they need medical information. In recent years, research in this area has focused on pharmacovigilance through social media, especially Twitter and medical forums and websites. This paper shows the information that can be gathered from a variety of Internet data sources and search engines, notably Google Trends and Google Correlate. Taking into account the case study of two popular medicines for severe depressive disorders (MDD), duloxetine and venlafaxine, we will provide a comparative analysis of their responses using publicly available alternative data sources.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: Methods
sections.text: The query index is based on query share: The total query volume for the search term in question is divided by the total number of query results in that region within a given geographical region. The horizontal axis of the main chart represents time (beginning in 2004), and the vertical is how often a term is searched by the total number of search results. This query index is available by country, state, and metro level for the United States and several other countries. On August 5, 2008, we launched Google Insights for Search, a more sophisticated and advanced service that displays search trends. On September 27, 2012, Google merged Google Insights for Search in Google Trends 36. Google classifies search results into categories at the level of search results at the classification level.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text: The results show that patients tend to be more interested in Cymbalta than Effexor. In addition, a review of the major events presented by medications in letters shows the response of patients to the drug milestones. For example, the approval of Cymbalta for muscle pain and chronic joint disease shows a good impact on web users for two years before returning to 2013. In addition, Table 1 lists the five most important related queries for each of the medications studied. The related queries reveal the high interest of web users with the side effects of both medications in the first place. Furthermore, consumers were interested in drug withdrawal and its effects. From the top queries of Cymbalta is "pain" and that can be explained by the fact that the FDA approved Cymbalta Cymbalta.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: We have shown how web data can facilitate medical research by providing an overview of the state of the art in this area of pharmacovigilance. While previous studies have relied mainly on Twitter and medical forums and websites to monitor medicines and find side effects, we have shown the importance of information that we can extract from alternative data sources such as Google Trends and Google Correlate, while we have examined the case study of duloxetine (Cymbalta) and venlafaxine (Effexor). This paper provides researchers with alternative tools to answer medical questions using web data, but we have only been able to analyze trends and data separately from different sources, mainly due to the large data imbalance associated with data from Twitter and Google. In the future, we will also analyze the series of events that influence trends and correlations.
